================
File: project/museum.md
================
---
title: Amanda Pinsker | Kleo
tag: Kleo
type: project
layout: project
image: "/img/og-img.png"
---



{:.full}
![Kleo cover image](/img/full/museum1.png)

# Background
A team of four students (Emily O'Brien, Evan McEldowney, Alice Young and Beatrice Huang) and I set out to explore the question: How might we create a memorable and accessible experience for novice visitors that creates interest and conversation between visitors and the museum itself?

### How might we...
- bridge the gap between physical and digital?
- support different interests of different visitors?
- support flexible decision making?
- create emotional/personal connections between museum goers and artifacts?
- add context to the content?
- encourage sharing?

# Audience
Based on academic papers we sourced, we identified our main audience as low-involvement museum visitors. We broke those people down into a few different segments.

1. **First time visitors**‚ÄîTourist, New local
1. **Repeat visitors**‚ÄîStudent, Experience seeker, Recharger, Specialist
1. **Facilitator**‚ÄîParent/Child, Teacher/Student

{:.full}
![](/img/full/museum8.png)






# Brainstorming
First, we filled out empathy maps for three audiences: Museum Goers, Curators and Museum Owners. A big takeaway from this exercise is that we needed to understand the museum‚Äôs perspective more.

After, we brainstormed problem statements. We picked out the problems we were most interested in and put them into buckets: How might we give visitors the confidence to not understand everything? How might we give visitors a tailored, meaningful experience? How might we measure our effectiveness?

Using these prompts, we brainstormed quick ideas for solutions. Looking back, a lot of our ideas from this brainstorming session made their way into our MVP.

{:.full}
![Museum logos](/img/full/museum5.png)
###### The museums in the Boston area that we spoke with.

# Professional interviews
Based on our exercise, we realized we needed to understand the museum's point of view more, so we set up interviews with professionals who worked with or at these organizations. These interviews were to empathize with a new audience, but we were also looking to potentially partner with a museum to execute the project.

At this point in our process, we were considering many avenues for a final product and deciding whether we wanted to partner with a local museum, use a space at Northeastern, or create a pop-up museum that explored our ideas. We decided to pursue a partnership because we thought that although we would need to deal with museum bureaucracy, it would give us the best opportunity to deal with space and a large collection of work. We were originally most interested in the MFA due to its proximity, traditional space, large collection, and it was a good example of the problems we identified.

{:.full}
![Sitemap](/img/full/museum6.png)
###### An early sitemap of the final app


# Proof of concept

After we knew the MFA wouldn‚Äôt be a viable partnership, we decided to pursue a mobile app. By working with this platform instead of working with large screens or installations, we will not need to worry about our work becoming rapidly obsolete, and our solution can easily extend to other museums. Additionally, our work can be easily created and implemented, allowing us to quickly learn from feedback and create improvements. Over about 3 weeks, we established the information architecture, sketched wireframes and started preliminary designs.

# Working with Harvard Art Museums
About halfway through the project, we met with the Harvard Art Museums and decided to move forward with using <a href="https://www.harvardartmuseums.org/collections/api">their open API</a> and designing the experience around their space.

{:.full}
![App screens](/img/full/museum7.png)

# Implementation
Once we decided on this direction, we designed the prototype iteratively based on in-person testing at the museum itself. Some ideas we explored in this phase included:

**Beacon technology** ‚Äî We explored placing beacons in the space to power experiences like letting users explore art near them in place


**Color based tours** ‚Äî Using the Harvard Art Museums' robust API, we could use their data to make unique kinds of tours.


**Creating your own tours** ‚Äî By simply letting users select from a list of works on view, then ordering those by room, we could easily create custom tours.

**Audio-based experience** ‚Äî Utilizing the beacon technology, we also began exploring voice and music based experiences that wouldn't require looking at your phone.

# Impact

In the end, we hope the project can be an example to institutions what is possible when a robust, thoughtful API is available. The project won the Humanities & Arts award at [Northeastern‚Äôs Research, Innovation, and Science Exposition (RISE)](https://www.northeastern.edu/rise/).

================
File: project/one-grid.html
================
---
title: Amanda Pinsker | Designer
tag: One Grid Candle Co.
type: project
layout: base
---


<section class='site-container'>

    {% include project-info.html %}
    <section class="project-section">
        <div class="project_img-container project_img-container--full">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/candle1.jpg" />
        </div>
        <div class="project_text-container">
            <p class="project_text">A major client during my internship at Tiny Rebels was One Grid. One Grid sells candles, and for each candle purchased, they donate a solar light to a family in need. We developed their branding, and designed all printed materials, along with their website. The client recently changed their name so some materials may feature the old logo.</p>
        </div>
        </div>
    </section>
    <section class="project-section">
        <div class="project_img-container project_img-container--xs">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/candle2.jpg" />
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container project_img-container--xs">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/candle3.jpg" />
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container project_img-container--xs">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/candle4.jpg" />
        </div>
        <div class="project_text-container">
            <p class="project_text">The logo was established just before I was hired. My first task was to design the label for the candles. The client wanted to include a section about the fragrance, a section about the company, information about the country, a tagline, and the candle specs.</p>
            <p class="project_text">The design fits with the visual identity we created, and all of the different fragrances together use a color palette that we established. The design balances emphasizing the charitable work the company is setting out to do with appealing to candle lovers. Photos of the finished candle are coming soon.</p>
        </div>
    </section>

    <section class="project-section">
        <div class="project_img-container project_img-container--med">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/one2.jpg" />
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/one6.jpg" />
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container project_img-container--med">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/one3.jpg" />
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/one4.jpg" />
        </div>
        <div class="project_text-container">
            <p class="project_text">For their website, we started out with wireframing. We decided early on the best solution would be one long scrolling page. The different sections we thought we would need changed over and over again, but the bulk of the website is for consumers to purchase the candles, or to sign up for a membership to be sent candles on a schedule. We spent a long time estabishing and making sure there was a clear hierarchy and navigation. We were sure to design responsively for tablet and mobile in addition to desktop. The website is not finalized, so what you see here is still missing some images, and includes some placeholder images and text.</p>
        </div>
    </section>
    {% include footer.html %}
</section>

================
File: project/pm-home.html
================
---
title: Amanda Pinsker | Designer
tag: Project Home
type: project
layout: base
---


<section class='site-container'>
    
    {% include project-info.html %}
    <section class="project-section">
        <div class="project_img-container col12">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/pmhome1.png"/>
        </div>
        <div class="project_text-container col6">
            <h3 class="project_subhead">Background</h3>
            <p class="project_text">Project Home was an initiative to improve the client and project management experience at Upstatement. It included quick links to conference lines, important files, and a roster of everyone working on the project. As a design apprentice at Upstatement, I worked on feature updates to the project.</p>
        </div>
        <div class="project_text-container col6">
            <h3 class="project_subhead">In This Case Study</h3>
            <p class="project_text">I worked on two features of this product:</p>
            <ol class="table-of-contents">
                <li><a href="#edit-mode">Edit Mode</a></li>
                <li><a class="link" href="#budget">Budget Reports</a></li>
            </ol>
    </section>
    <!-- <hr> -->
    <section class="project-section" id="edit-mode">
        <h2 class="col12">Edit Mode</h2>
        <div class="project_img-container col12">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/pmhome3.png"/>
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Piece of final design</h5>
        </div>
        <div class="project_text-container col6">
            <h3 class="project_subhead">Problem</h3>
            <p class="project_text">Employees at Upstatement had to go to the Wordpress back-end to edit anything on the page, which was frustrating and time consuming.</p>
        </div>
        <div class="project_text-container col6">
            <h3 class="project_subhead">Goal</h3>
            <p class="project_text">I was tasked with establishing a way to edit a project from the interface itself.</p>
        </div>
        <div class="project_text-container col12">
            <h3 class="project_subhead">Research</h3>
            <p class="project_text col4">We decided to implement editing section by section, so that we could iterate and use what we were designing before implementing it globally. We started with the Links section.I investigated the WordPress backend and listed out all of the data that needed to be edited or added:</p>
            <ul>
                <li>Link URL (string)</li>
                <li>Link Name (string)</li>
                <li>Link Type (single select)</li>
                <li>Hide from client (checkbox)</li>
                <li>Date</li>
                <li>File upload</li>
            </ul>
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col8">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/pmhome2.png"/>
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Edit mode inspiration</h5>
        </div>
        <div class="project_text-container col4">
            <p class="project_text">I also looked at other products and how they let users edit information. A big point of inspiration was Squarespace.</p>
        </div>
        <div class="project_text-container col6">
            <h3 class="project_subhead">Explorations</h3>
            <p class="project_text">I first experimented with a modal style, but we thought it would be more intuitive and less time consuming if the editing could take place in context. We also decided to simplify and automate this information, which cut the data input down to:</p>
            <ul>
                <li>Link URL (string)</li>
                <li>Link Name (string)</li>
                <li>Hide from client (checkbox)</li>
            </ul>
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col6">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/pmhome4.png"/>
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">First sketch</h5>
        </div>
        <div class="project_text-container col4">
            <p class="project_text">I then explored creating an ‚ÄúEdit Mode,‚Äù that mimics the interface itself and lets you quickly edit in context. The colors invert, letting the user know they are in a different mode. The user can then click on an icon to expand the edit fields, which then automatically save.</p>
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col12">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/pmhome7.png"/>
        </div>
        <div class="project_text-container col12">
            <h3 class="project_subhead">The details</h3>
            <p class="project_text col4">I worked to establish patterns such as empty states, indicating saving status, reordering links, and entering edit mode.</p>
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col6">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/pmhome8.png"/>
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Saving states</h5>
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col6">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/pmhome9.png"/>
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Drag to reorder</h5>
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col6">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/pmhome10.png"/>
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Empty state</h5>
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col6">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/pmhome11.png"/>
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Entering edit mode</h5>
        </div>

        <div class="project_text-container col4">
            <h3 class="project_subhead">Adding more</h3>
            <p class="project_text ">I worked with the developer on the project to implement this, then worked on applying it to the roster. This added an extra layer of information, since the user needed to be able to add a team, and then add people to that team. To deal with this, I experimented with how to edit the team name, and how to create a hierarchy between adding a team vs adding a person. Editing a person simply followed the patterns that I established with the links section.

        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col8">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/pmhome12.png"/>
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Editing roster</h5>
        </div>
        <div class="project_text-container col12">
            <h3 class="project_subhead">In the end</h3>
            <p class="project_text col4">Upstatement Producers can now easily create and edit projects without dealing with frustrating Wordpress forms.</p>
        </div>

    </section>

    <section class="project-section" id="budget">
        <h2 class="col12">Budget Reports</h2>
        <div class="project_img-container col12">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/pmhome19.png"/>
        </div>
        <div class="project_text-container col6">
            <h3 class="project_subhead">Problem</h3>
            <p class="project_text">Clients at Upstatement received weekly updates of how much of their budget has been used, and how much time was left in the project. This email couldn‚Äôt visualize any information, and had to be done manually by Upstatement‚Äôs studio manager.</p>
        </div>
        <div class="project_text-container col6">
            <h3 class="project_subhead">Goal</h3>
            <p class="project_text">Visualize a project‚Äôs budget and time so that clients can easily understand where they currently are at through the project, and can make decisions about how to manage their money and time left.</p>
        </div>
        <div class="project_text-container col6">
            <h3 class="project_subhead">Research</h3>
            <p class="project_text">I interviewed the Studio Manager to understand how the budget worked, and how this process was currently working. Each week, the Studio Manager manually checked the project‚Äôs budget through Upstatement‚Äôs time tracking system, checked how many weeks through the project they were, and calculated a percentage to demonstrate whether the project was over budget or not. This email would say, for example, ‚ÄúWe've completed 10 of 22 weeks (45.45%) and have used¬†43.23% of the target budget.‚Äù</p>
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col6">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/pmhome18.png"/>
        </div>
        <div class="project_text-container col12">
            <h3 class="project_subhead">Explorations</h3>
            <p class="project_text col4">I explored many ways to visualize this information, eventually landing on the visualization below. We felt that visualization had the most clarity for the context of checking whether the budget was above or below the current timeline.</p>
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col4">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/pmhome14.png"/>
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Exploration sketches</h5>
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col4">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/pmhome15.png"/>
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col4">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/pmhome16.png"/>
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col12">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/pmhome17.png"/>
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Final direction</h5>
        </div>
        <div class="project_text-container col12">
            <h3 class="project_subhead">Final Product</h3>
            <p class="project_text col4">I implemented a static version of my designs and collaborated with the developer on the project to implement the details of the edge cases such as how it would work responsively, and with different edge cases, such as a large amount of weeks, and going over budget or time. This process is now automated and always available to clients via PM Home.</p>
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col9">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/pmhome13.png"/>
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Large amount of weeks</h5>
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/pmhome21.png"/>
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Over budget and time</h5>
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col3">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/pmhome20.png"/>
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">On mobile</h5>
        </div>

    </section>
    {% include footer.html %}
</section>

================
File: project/posters.html
================
---
title: Amanda Pinsker | Designer
tag: Posters
type: project
layout: base
---


<section class='site-container'>

    {% include project-info.html %}
    <section class="project-section">
        <div class="project_img-container project_img-container--full">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/broadside5.jpg" />
        </div>
        <div class="project_text-container">
            <p class="project_text">Various poster work. </br></br>Showcasing the typeface, Meta. The challenge was to present the history and feel of a chosen typeface at a large scale. The broadside showcases the elegant, humanistic feel of Meta, and that is best captured by the typeface's lowercase "g." Looking further, the viewer then can inspect the character set, characteristics of the typface, and a history of the typeface. All elements were carefully laid out on the page to create a dynamic composition and colors were chosen to create a deliberate relationship between figure and ground.</p>
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container project_img-container--full">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/doas4.jpg" />
        </div>
        <div class="project_text-container">
            <p class="project_text">Poster designed for "Death of a Salesman."  The orange peel is inspired by the line, "You can‚Äôt eat the orange, and throw the peel away ‚Äì a man is not a piece of fruit." The story of "Death of a Salesman" details the decline of the main character, Willy Loman. The orange peel is meant to represent this decline. The type treatment of the title and author is meant to mimic the movement of the orange peel.</p>
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container project_img-container--full">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/futurism4.jpg" />
        </div>
        <div class="project_text-container">
            <p class="project_text">The Futurist Manifesto typeset in the style of the Futurism Movement. The project works to make the content of the message show though the design, and does so through systematically breaking typographic rules. The message is loud, unconventional, and harsh, therefore, so is the design.</p>
        </div>
    </section>
    {% include footer.html %}
</section>

================
File: project/sixties.html
================
---
title: Amanda Pinsker | Designer
tag: 1960s Ads and Culture
type: project
layout: base
---


<section class='site-container'>

    {% include project-info.html %}
    <div class="project-section">
        <div class="project_img-container project_img-container--full">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/sixties1.jpg" />
        </div>
        <div class="project_text-container">
            <p class="project_text">Two different topics designed to exist on the same page. I used different visual systems to convey their meaning and make them stand apart from each other. Running on the top is 1960s Advertising, set in Century Expanded, a typeface used commonly in the imagery.
            <p class="project_text">Along the bottom is 1960s Psychedelic Culture, set in Futura, another typeface from the period chosen to contrast the funky, psychedelic posters.</p>
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container project_img-container--xs">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/sixties4.jpg" />
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container project_img-container--xs">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/sixties5.jpg" />
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container project_img-container--xs">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/sixties6.jpg" />
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container project_img-container--sm">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/sixties2.jpg" />
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container project_img-container--large">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/sixties3.jpg" />
        </div>
    </div>
    {% include footer.html %}
</section>

    <section class="project-section">
        <div class="project_img-container col12">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/tastemakers1.jpg"/>
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Tastemakers issue covers</h5>
        </div>
        <div class="project_text-container col12">
            <p class="project_text col4">I, along with my co-art director, am in charge of a team of student designers. We follow a style guide to keep the magazine consistent and cohesive. Each designer on the team designs a spread which is critiqued by the group. We then combine the team's spreads into the final magazine.</p>
        </div>

================
File: project/transforming-medicine.html
================
---
title: Amanda Pinsker | Designer
tag: Transforming Medicine
type: project
layout: base
---

<section class='site-container'>
    
    {% include project-info.html %}
    <section class="project-section">
        <div class="project_img-container col12">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/tmed1.jpg" />
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Landing page</h5>
        </div>
        <div class="project_text-container col12">
            <p class="project_text col4">Transforming Medicine is a nonprofit dedicated to changing how cancer patients are diagnosed and treated. Ronik was hired to do their branding and website. I helped to design key features of the final website, spent a lot of time working on the mobile version, and worked closely with the branding portion of the project.</p>
        </div>
    </section>

    <section class="project-section">
        <div class="project_img-container col4">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/tmed3.jpg" />
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Mission page</h5>
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col4">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/tmed5.jpg" />
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">About page</h5>
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col4">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/tmed6.jpg" />
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Media page</h5>
        </div>

        <div class="project_text-container col12">
            <h3 class="project_subhead">Designing the website</h3>
            <p class="project_text col4">We began by working off of initial directions designed by the design directors. Our challenges were to make the text heavy pages visually interesting, and how to lead users through the site. We focused on a footer that would not be a dead end, and would also hold the call to action to sign up for the email list.</p>
        </div>
    </section>

    <section class="project-section">
        <div class="project_img-container col3">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/tmed8.jpg" />
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Working mobile screens</h5>
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col3">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/tmed10.jpg" />
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col3">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/tmed9.jpg" />
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col3">
            <img class="project_img last" src="/img/full/tmed13.jpg" />
        </div>
        <div class="project_text-container col12">
            <h3 class="project_subhead">Designing for mobile</h3>
            <p class="project_text col4">Considering the text heavy pages we had, we spent a lot of time making sure the text was comfortable to read on mobile. We also dealt with challenges such as how the home screen would function, and how the subnavigation would work. </p>
        </div>
    </section>
    <section class="project-section">
        <div class="project_img-container col3">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/tmed11.jpg" />
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Different footer treatments</h5>
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col3">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/tmed12.jpg" />
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col3">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/tmed14.jpg" />
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col3">
            <img class="project_img last" src="/img/full/tmed15.jpg" />
        </div>
        <div class="project_text-container col12">
            <h3 class="project_subhead">Designing the footer for mobile</h3>
            <p class="project_text col4">A challenge that we iterated on was the mobile footer. We played around with what the buttons to the other pages could look like, and how big they would need to be. After spending some time on it, we decided to leave the buttons out, as we had a sticky header that would make the navigation always available.</p>
        </div>
    </section>

    <section class="project-section">
        <div class="project_img-container col4">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/tmed24.jpg" />
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Direction A</h5>
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col8">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/tmed25.jpg" />
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col4">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/tmed30.jpg" />
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Direction B</h5>
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col8">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/tmed31.jpg" />
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col4">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/tmed29.jpg" />
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Direction C</h5>
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col8">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/tmed28.jpg" />
        </div>


        <div class="project_text-container col12">
            <h3 class="project_subhead">Early logos</h3>
            <p class="project_text col4">As the website was being designed, we were also sketching logos. The client wanted a light and airy mark that evoked the ideas of science and big data. The logo was also influenced by the natural imagery we were gravitating towards for the headers.</p>
        </div>
    </section>

    <section class="project-section">
        <div class="project_img-container col4">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/tmed36.jpg" />
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Final Direction A</h5>
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col8">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/tmed37.jpg" />
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col4">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/tmed34.jpg" />
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Final Direction B</h5>
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col8">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/tmed35.jpg" />
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col12">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/tmed38.jpg" />
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Final branding</h5>
        </div>
        <div class="project_text-container col12">
            <h3 class="project_subhead">The final branding</h3>
            <p class="project_text col4">The final logo is geometric, light and considers the idea of change. The logo is presented on organic photography that are semi-abstract images of nature.</p>
        </div>
    </section>

    <section class="project-section">
        <div class="project_img-container col9">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/tmed17.jpg" />
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/tmed16.jpg" />
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/tmed18.jpg" />
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Final desktop screens</h5>
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col3">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/tmed19.jpg" />
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Home screen</h5>
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/tmed20.jpg" />
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Open sub navigation</h5>
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/tmed21.jpg" />
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Final footer direction</h5>
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/tmed22.jpg" />
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Mission screen</h5>
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/tmed23.jpg" />
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Navigation mid-scroll</h5>

        </div>
        <div class="project_text-container col12">
            <h3 class="project_subhead">The final website</h3>
            <p class="project_text col4">Through lots of tweaking type and debating header images, we designed a website that presented Transforming Medicine's cause in an inspiring and engaging way.</p>
        </div>
    </section>
    {% include footer.html %}
</section>

================
File: project/wellthy.html
================
---
title: Amanda Pinsker | Designer
tag: Wellthy
type: project
layout: base
---

<section class='site-container'>
    
    {% include project-info.html %}
    <section class="project-section">
        <div class="project_img-container col12">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/wellthy1.jpg"/>
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Customer dashboard, desktop and mobile</h5>
        </div>
        <div class="project_text-container col12">
            <p class="project_text col4">Wellthy is a service aiming to provide assistance to adult children overwhelmed with caring for a sickly parent. Wellthy provides their clients with a health planner who can assist with tasks such as finding reputable doctors, making appointments, coordinating between hospitals, or arranging transportation.</p>
            <p class="project_text col4">Ronik assisted with providing a web application for the health planner to easily manage and communicate updates to their customers. This would easily keep all of their information in one place, prevent confusion, and make communication more streamlined. I was part of the UX and design team and helped hash out functionality and UI design decisions.</p>
        </div>
    </section>

    <section class="project-section">
        <div class="project_img-container col6">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/wellthy3.jpg"/>
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Page flows</h5>
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col6">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/wellthy10.png"/>
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/wellthy11.png"/>
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Wireframes: home page, onboarding</h5>
        </div>
        <div class="project_text-container col12">
            <h3 class="project_subhead">Flows and Wireframing</h3>
            <p class="project_text col4">The flow is relatively simple. The health planner and the customer have different views of the same information, along with an account settings page. The health planner also needed a screen to view all of their customers. We were also tweaking a few links on their home page, such as the addition of a login button, and polishing their onboarding screens. We had to account for the period of time when a customer is signed up but not assigned to a health planner yet.</p>
        </div>
    </section>

    <section class="project-section">
        <div class="project_img-container col6">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/wellthy7.png"/>
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/wellthy8.jpg"/>
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/wellthy9.jpg"/>
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Wireframes: customer views</h5>
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col6">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/wellthy4.png"/>
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/wellthy5.jpg"/>
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/wellthy6.jpg"/>
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Wireframes: health planner views</h5>
        </div>
        <div class="project_text-container col12">
            <p class="project_text col4">The customer sees a dashboard with information about their health planner, contact information, and updates. Updates are marked as unread or read, with a timestamp. The customer can also view a description of what their health planner can do for them. The health planner dashboard allows them to post updates, view information about the patient that the customer entered during onboarding, and the customer contact information. The health planner can see if the customer has read their update. They can also edit the patient's current "care priorities."</p>
            <p class="project_text col4">Account settings for both function in the same manner. The user can click on a pencil icon to update a single item, instead of sending the whole form each time something needs to be updated.</p>
        </div>
    </section>

    <section class="project-section">
        <div class="project_img-container col9">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/wellthy14.jpg"/>
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Designs: health planner dashboard</h5>
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col3">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/wellthy15.jpg"/>
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Designs: customer account settings</h5>
        </div>
        <div class="project_text-container col12">
            <h3 class="project_subhead">Adding Visual Design</h3>
            <p class="project_text col4">Moving into the design phase was simple, considering the simple and clean style the client desired. We applied their brand blue for interactive elements, also using yellow and red for preferences and error states. We didn't wireframe for mobile and instead figured out the challenges for mobile through the design phase.</p>
        </div>
    </section>

    <section class="project-section">
        <div class="project_img-container col12">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/wellthy16.png"/>
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col6">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/wellthy17.png"/>
            <h5 class="project_img-caption">Designs: community manager screens</h5>
        </div>
        <div class="project_img-container col6">
            <img class="project_img" src="/img/full/wellthy18.png"/>
        </div>
        <div class="project_text-container col12">
            <h3 class="project_subhead">Adding administration tools</h3>
            <p class="project_text col4">Lastly, we added a flow for a "community manager" to be able to view all health planners and their customers.</p>
            <p class="project_text col4">In the end, we created a clearly designed system that would make their employees' and customers' lives easier, and would be easy for Wellthy to expand as their company grew.</p>
        </div>
    </section>


    {% include footer.html %}
</section>

================
File: reading/reading.html
================
---
title: Amanda Pinsker | Reading
name: reading
layout: reading
permalink: reading
---

<div class="reading-nav">
  <a href="/">Back</a>
</div>

<section class="reading-container">
  <h1 class="book-title book-scroll">Books I've read
    <span>and where I read them</span><a href="#hey">*</a>
  </h1>

  {% for item in site.data.reading %}
    <div class="book" id="{{ item.url }}">
      <h2 class="date book-scroll">
        <a href="#{{ item.url }}">{{ item.date }}</a>
      </h2>
      <span class="pic-container">
        <img class="book-img book-scroll" src="{{ item.book_img }}" alt="Cover of {{ item.title }}"/>
        {% if item.pic_img %}
          <img class="pic-img book-scroll" src="{{ item.pic_img }}" alt="Picture {{ item.place }}"/>
        {% endif %}
        {% if item.video %}
          <video width="330" height="440" class="pic-img" autoplay>
            <source src="{{ item.video }}" type="video/mp4">
            Your browser does not support the video tag.
          </video>
        {% endif %}
      </span>

      <span class="info">
        <h2 class="title book-scroll">{{ item.title }}
          <span>{{ item.place }}</span>
        </h2>
        <p class="description book-scroll"> {{ item.description }}</p>
        {% if item.highlights %}
          <span class="highlight book-scroll no-quote">
            <h5>Underlined</h5>
            {% for highlight in item.highlights %}
            <h6>{{ highlight }}</h6>
            {% endfor %}
          </span>
        {% endif %}
      </span>
    </div>
  {% endfor %}
</section>

<div id="hey">* Are these dates real? Are these locations real? Who cares? Why did you even click on this? Go <a href="/reading">get back</a> to what you were doing.</div>

================
File: writing/reading-advice.md
================
---
title: A Grown Up's Guide to Reading
description: A collection of advice I frequently give about reading
layout: post
---

# A Grown Up's Guide to Reading
## A collection of advice I frequently give about reading

---

I‚Äôve had a really common reading experience as a lot of people. I was, as they say, a voracious reader as a kid. Then, somewhere along the way, I kind of just stopped. Maybe high school turned reading into homework, or maybe I was so busy in college that it became hard to keep up with. But either way, I found myself still holding onto this identity as ‚Äúa reader‚Äù without having read a book, especially one outside of The Canon[^1], in years.

I still probably don‚Äôt read as much as it might seem, but I‚Äôve found a much happier, more productive[^2] relationship to reading and I think that all starts with my first reminder:


## Reading is fun
The reason I read a lot as a kid was very simple: ‚Äã*it was fun*. I wasn‚Äôt doing it to Learn for the sake of it necessarily. I wasn‚Äôt doing it to fulfill my identity as a Reader.  I did it for the reason most kids do things: I had fun doing it.

Life doesn‚Äôt need to be so serious all the time. There are a lot of reasons to read. Sometimes it‚Äôs to grow, sometimes it‚Äôs to learn about something, sometimes it‚Äôs to make sure I still have a semblance of an attention span, sometimes it‚Äôs to get my mind off things, sometimes it‚Äôs to laugh. I grow from being silly and having fun just as much as I do from being serious. And reading doesn‚Äôt always need to be about growing, it can also just be dumb. There are bad books just as much as there‚Äôs bad TV, but sometimes something dumb is fun and that‚Äôs what we need at that moment.

The people I know who read the most are the ones who take it the least seriously. They aren‚Äôt the I Set A Goal To Read 100 Books In A Year ones. They read a lot because it‚Äôs a way they like to spend their time.


## Don‚Äôt feel guilty dropping books
This is probably the biggest thing that got me reading more. As soon as reading something becomes a chore ‚Äã**stop reading it**‚Äã. Whenever I have the thought *"maybe I should read tonight"* and I feel a pit in my stomach, I stop reading that book.

*But isn‚Äôt it worth pushing through that? Don‚Äôt some books get better?* Maybe that‚Äôs true! But you won‚Äôt get to that point if you dread reading the book. Maybe a different you will find the book again in the future and want to give it another go. Maybe that you will be you next week, but the you right now really doesn‚Äôt wanna be reading that book. Save reading difficult-to-get-through books for when you have some good reading momentum.

I am often in the middle of multiple books at a time. I‚Äôll read one book when I need something lighter, and read another when I feel like digging into something meatier. There are no rules! You don‚Äôt have to finish a book before moving on to the next one on your list. You don‚Äôt have to read one book at a time. You don‚Äôt *have* to do anything, because your life isn‚Äôt English class.


## Fiction is good for your soul
I read a pretty even mix of fiction and nonfiction, but I‚Äôve met a lot of other grown-ups who never read fiction and that makes me very sad. When I ask why they often say that fiction feels frivolous or that they should be using that time to learn about something.

Allow me to give you my quick, very earnest, pitch about fiction if you need to hear it.

Nonfiction might help you learn about a topic, but fiction helps you learn about life! The human condition! I dunno, your own soul! I learn so much more through fiction, and if that‚Äôs surprising to you, you need to expand your definition of learning. Stories put words to the mysterious, the things you thought couldn‚Äôt be made concrete, the felt but not seen. Stories pull water from the mist in the air.

I am a more empathetic person because I read fiction. I‚Äôm a good storyteller because I read fiction. I know myself on a deeper level because I read fiction. I understand the world better because I read fiction. I‚Äôm more in touch with my imagination because I read fiction. Fiction helps me understand how much perspective can change a narrative, which is a skill we could all use these days.

If you don‚Äôt read fiction, here‚Äôs your nudge to try it. I feel a little silly even talking about fiction like this because it‚Äôs such a huge genre. I fully believe everyone can find something they like. Yes, even as a grown-up.[^3]


## Take notes, but not too seriously
This one you can take or leave, but I like to read with a pen. I feel like it helps me pay attention as I‚Äôm reading, it helps me read a little deeper, and it helps me come back to things that stuck out, made me feel something, made me laugh, was a particularly beautiful turn of phrase, the list goes on and on. Honestly, my most frequent note is probably ‚Äúlol.‚Äù It doesn‚Äôt need to be that deep. Yes, I physically destroy my books with this. It‚Äôs fine. They‚Äôre not library books. If you don‚Äôt want to use a pen, use a highlighter, use post its, use the highlighter on your kindle. Just try it and see if it helps you. If it feels like a chore, or it's taking too much work, forget it! I‚Äôm not the boss of you! [^4]



## Independent bookstores have _great_ book recommendations
It can be hard to break out of The Canon if that‚Äôs what you‚Äôre used to, but independent bookstores are genuinely an amazing way to find new books. This is the second biggest thing that got me out of my reading rut.

Walk into any independent bookstore where you live and there will probably be a Staff Picks shelf.[^5] Or a Bestsellers shelf. And probably plenty of other fun sections that speak to you. My favorite stores have personally written notecards with their favorite books. Plus, there are really lovely people there whose whole job is to talk to you about books. The books you‚Äôll find will be interesting, different, often contemporary books that weren‚Äôt written decades ago by a dead white guy. They will be books that speak to our lives today, and books that stretch your idea of what a good book can be. Maybe you‚Äôll get exposed to short story collections[^6], poetry, or graphic novels.

If you don‚Äôt live near a bookstore, a lot of places will post recommendations on their site or in their email newsletters.

If you live in NYC or SF (sorry I‚Äôm a coastal elitist), or you don‚Äôt live near an independent bookstore, here are some quick plugs of my favorites, and links to their online recommendations.

#### **1. The Booksmith**‚ÄîHaight Ashbury, San Francisco  
  - [Staff Picks](https://www.booksmith.com/BSF)
  - [Bestsellers](https://www.booksmith.com/BST)

#### **2. Dog Eared Books**‚ÄîThe Mission, San Francisco
  - [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/dogearedvalencia/?hl=en)

#### **3. Green Apple Books**‚ÄîThe Richmond & The Sunset, San Francisco
  - [Staff Favorites](https://www.greenapplebooks.com/staff-faves1)
  - [New Books We Like](https://www.greenapplebooks.com/new-books-we-like)

#### **4. City Light Books**‚ÄîNorth Beach, San Francisco
  - [Staff Picks](https://citylights.com/staff-picks/)
  - [Browse the Shelves](https://citylights.com/bookstore/browse-our-shelves/)

#### **5. Books Are Magic**‚ÄîCobble Hill, Brooklyn
  - [Staff Picks](https://booksaremagic.net/staff-picks)
  - [Book Lists](https://booksaremagic.net/browse/book-lists)

#### **6. McNally Jackson**‚ÄîVarious locations around Manhattan
  - [Staff Picks](https://www.mcnallyjackson.com/new-staff-picks)
  - [Monthly Bestsellers](https://www.mcnallyjackson.com/monthly-bestsellers)

#### **7. Greenlight Books**‚ÄîFort Greene, Brooklyn
  - [Staff Picks](https://www.greenlightbookstore.com/staffpicks)

#### **8. Word Bookstore**‚ÄîGreenpoint, Brooklyn & Jersey City, NJ
  - [Staff Picks](https://shop.wordbookstores.com/staffpicks)
  - [Monthly Staff Picks](https://shop.wordbookstores.com/march-staff-picks)


## There are no rules
If there‚Äôs anything I hope you take away it's this. Read on a Kindle. Read physical books. Read on both depending on your mood. Listen to audiobooks. Read four books at a time. Who cares! Do what feels right to you and find books that make you fall in love with reading.

---

[^1]: Books you might get assigned in a high school English class, for example.
[^2]: Productive here defined simply as: I read more!
[^3]: YA is still fun as an adult too.
[^4]: I like to share my messy hardcopies with friends and have this romantic notion that it's as if they're reading the book along with me. My friends disagree and find my "lol"s very distracting.
[^5]: If you‚Äôre lucky, the Staff Picks shelf will have the bookseller‚Äôs name, and if you like something on there, you can assume you might like their other recommendations.
[^6]: I did, which mini tip: is also a great way to get out of a rut.

        <div class='about__img'><img src="/img/small/me.jpg"/></div>
        <div class="about__content">
            <p>I'm a Product Designer at GitHub based in San Francisco. As a designer, I like hard problems, smart type, fun hover interactions, and compassionate design. As a person, I enjoy pretending I know how to play the piano, buying Moleskine notebooks that I don't need, and making self-deprecating jokes.</p>
        </div>
    </div>
    <div class="about-info-container">
        <div id="contact" class="about-info">

---
title: Nicholas Jaffer | Student and Dev
name: home
layout: base
image: "/img/og-img.png"
---

<div class="bg"></div>
<main class="site-container">
  <div class="home">
    <div class="intro">
      <div>
        <h1><span class="hint" title="Type my name and see what happens">Nicholas</span> Jaffer</h1> ‚Äî Student & Dev-In-Training.
      </div>
      <div>I'm available for part time work summer 2025. <a href="mailto:plyght@peril.lol">Reach out</a> if you'd like to work together.</div>
      <hr class="accent">
    </div>
    <div class="flex">
      <div class="work column">
        <h2>Selected work</h2>
        {% for item in site.data.portfolio %}
          {% if item.show %}
          <a class="project" id="{{ item.id }}" onmouseover="addClass(body, '{{ item.id }}');" onmouseout="removeClass(body, '{{ item.id }}');" href="{{ item.url }}">
            <b>{{ item.title }}</b>‚Äî{{ item.description }}{% if item.external%}<span class="accent external-link">&#8599;&#xFE0E;</span>{% endif %}
          </a>
          {% endif %}
        {% endfor %}



      </div>
      <div class="about column">
        <div class="collaborators"> 
          <h2>Recent collaborators</h2>
          <div>
            <a href="https://prose.com/">Prose</a><span class="accent external-link">&#8599;&#xFE0E;</span>
          </div>
          <div>
            <a href="https://www.ustwo.com/">ustwo</a><span class="accent external-link">&#8599;&#xFE0E;</span>
          </div>
        </div>
        <h2>A little about me</h2>
        <div>Right now, I am a sophmore at <a href="https://wl.apsva.us">Washington-Liberty High School</a>. I was focused on how you work with GitHub from your local machine. All of our work was <a href="http://github.com/desktop/desktop">open</a>&nbsp;<a href="http://github.com/cli/cli">source</a><span class="accent superscript" id="asterisk" onmouseover="addClass(asterisk2, 'footnote-accent');" onmouseout="removeClass(asterisk2, 'footnote-accent');">*</span>.</div>
        <div>Before that, I spent some time at <a>Upstatement</a> and <a>Ronik</a>, led the crew at <a>Scout</a>, and graduated from&nbsp;<a>Northeastern</a><span class="accent superscript" id="dagger" onmouseover="addClass(dagger2, 'footnote-accent');" onmouseout="removeClass(dagger2, 'footnote-accent');">‚Ä†</span>.</div>
        <div>I grew up in the ‚Äòburbs of New York<span class="accent superscript" id="doubledagger" onmouseover="addClass(doubledagger2, 'footnote-accent');" onmouseout="removeClass(doubledagger2, 'footnote-accent');">‚Ä°</span>, make a lot of self deprecating jokes<span class="accent superscript" id="section" onmouseover="addClass(section2, 'footnote-accent');" onmouseout="removeClass(section2, 'footnote-accent');">¬ß</span>, and I'm notorious for being average at a thousand hobbies‚Äîmost recently <strike>guitar</strike> piano, <strike>mini</strike> Monday crossword puzzles, <strike>knitting</strike> wire sculpting, and journaling.<span class="accent superscript" id="paragraph" onmouseover="addClass(paragraph2, 'footnote-accent');" onmouseout="removeClass(paragraph2, 'footnote-accent');">¬∂</span></div>
        <div class="notes grid">
          <span class="accent">*</span><p class="note" id="asterisk2"><span>So is <a href="https://github.com/ampinsk/ampinsk.github.io">this</a>. And it was built by moi.</span></p>
          <span class="accent">‚Ä†</span><p class="note" id="dagger2"><span>Here's my <a href="/pinsker-resume-2021.pdf">resume</a> if you need it.</span></p>
          <span class="accent">‚Ä°</span><p class="note" id="doubledagger2"><span>Long Island, specifically. At least it's not Jersey.</span></p>
          <span class="accent">¬ß</span><p class="note" id="section2"><span>I didn't get away with these as well as I'd liked on the West Coast.</span></p>
          <span class="accent">¬∂</span><p class="note" id="paragraph2"><span>If you've learned about me and would still like to talk to me, you can do so in these places: <a href="http://twitter.com/ampinsk">Twitter</a>, <a href="mailto:apinsker4@gmail.com">Email</a>, <a href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/amandapinsker/">LinkedIn</a>.</span></p>
          <span class="accent optically-smaller">&#8599;&#xFE0E;</span><p class="note" id="external2"><span>This means I do not have a public case study yet  and I must send you somewhere else.</span></p>
        </div>

      </div>
    </div>
  </div>
</main>

================
File: main.scss
================
---
---

// Import Partials
@import "mq";
@import "variables";
@import "project";
@import "reading";
@import "navigation";
@import "home";
@import "writing";
@import "easter-egg";
@import "hover";

// General Styles

body {
  font-family: $primary-font;
  background-color: $background;
  color: $foreground;
  margin: 0;
  line-height: 1.3;
  transition: $timing;
  font-size: 16px;
}

.site-container {
  width: 88%;
  margin: 0 auto;
  max-width: 1300px;
  padding: 80px 0;

  @include mq($tablet) {
    width: 72%;
  }
}

a {
  position: relative;
  color: $foreground;
  text-decoration: none;
  cursor: pointer;
  transition: $timing;
}

h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6, p {
  margin: 0;
}

.back {
  font-size: 18px;
  font-family: $serif-text;
  text-decoration: none;

  span {
    display: inline-block;
    transition: $timing;
  }

  &:hover {
    text-decoration: none;

    span {
      transform: translateX(-5px);
      transition: $timing;
    }
  }

  @include mq($tablet) {
    margin-left: -22px;
  }
}

.disabled {
  opacity: 50%;
  pointer-events: none;
}

.third {
  @include mq($tablet) {
    display: inline-block;
    width: 33%;
  }
}

.half {
  @include mq($tablet) {
    display: inline-block;
    width: 48%;
  }
}

.full {
  width: 100%;
}

.left {
  float: left;
}

.right {
  float: right;
}



p::selection,
h6::selection,
h5::selection,
h4::selection,
h3::selection,
h2::selection,
h1::selection,
img::selection,
a::selection,
span::selection,
div::selection,
b::selection,
strike::selection {
  background: $foreground;
  color: $background;

  @media (prefers-color-scheme: dark) {
    background: $background;
    color: $foreground;
  }
}



// Dark Mode
// ---------


@media (prefers-color-scheme: dark) {
  body {
    background-color: $foreground;
    color: $background;
  }

  a {
    color: $background;
  }

  .note span  {
    box-shadow: inset 0px 0px 0px 0px darken($red, 20%);
  }

  .footnote-accent span {
    box-shadow: inset 0px -25px 0px 0px darken($red, 20%);
  }

  .project-intro .site-button {
    border-color: $background;

    &:hover {
      background: $background;
      color: $foreground;
    }
  }

  .footer {
    border-color: $background;
  }

  @keyframes easter-egg-accent {
    2%  {color: $black; border-color: $black;}
    98%  {color: $black; border-color: $black;}
  }
}

================
File: README.md
================
# Portfolio

My portfolio site: home of my [past work](http://amandapinsker.com), a current [side project](http://amandapinsker.com/reading), and hopefully future ones.
